column4: hello, I use ubuntu and I installed KDE using "sudo aptitude install KDE"  I selected gdm as my login manager.  When I try to start a KDE session I get an error telling me to make sure the dcopserver program is running.  what is that/
Is the kdebase-bin package installed?
In answer to your "what is it" question, dcop is a communication protocol which allows KDE applications to talk to one another. Or you to talk to them.
kdebase-bin package is installed
Does KDE let you log in? Or does it kick you out?
it kicks me out.  the error appears right after the splash screen appears.  when I click "ok" it goes back to gdm
Do you know about the virtual terminals?
I'm assuming you also have and want to use gnome on this system?
run the "dcopserver" command in gnome\fluxbox\whatever. See what it says.
there was no terminal output
That may be either good or bad. Try starting kde now.
ok brb'
it did not work.  the error says "could not read network connection list. /home/matthew/.DCOPserver_matthew-laptop__0"
And there's nothing weird about your home dir?
there is no file by that name in my home dir
You could temporarily try kdm and see if it works. But I don't know what's wrong; everything you described sounds fine. Don't see why that file is missing.
I need to add something to my path.  do you know how to do that?
If your question is "what do I need to add to my PATH", I have no idea. If your question is, "I need to add /usr/foo/bar to my PATH," I can.
yes, someone with a similar problem added /etc/X11R6/bin to their path and it worked
Problem is, I'm not sure whether that needs to be added to root path or to user path.
Try user's path first, I suppose... add this to ~/.bashrc: export PATH=$PATH:/etc/X11R6/bin
